## Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS)

The Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS) is a French national research agency that was established in 1939. It is one of the largest and most prestigious research organizations in the world.

## History

The CNRS was established in 1939 as a result of the merger of several smaller research organizations. The first director of the CNRS was André Lichnerowicz, who served from 1939 to 1945. The CNRS played a significant role in the development of nuclear physics and was involved in the development of the first nuclear reactor.

## Research

The CNRS is involved in a wide range of research activities, including physics, chemistry, biology, and mathematics. The organization is also involved in the development of new technologies, such as renewable energy and advanced materials.

## Structure

The CNRS is organized into several directorates, each responsible for a specific area of research. The directorates are:

* Directorate of Physics
* Directorate of Chemistry
* Directorate of Biology
* Directorate of Mathematics
* Directorate of Advanced Materials
* Directorate of Renewable Energy

## Funding

The CNRS is funded by the French government and receives an annual budget of approximately €1.5 billion. The organization also receives funding from other sources, such as the European Union and private companies.

## International collaborations

The CNRS is involved in international collaborations with other research organizations around the world. The organization has partnerships with institutions such as the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) and the National Science Foundation (NSF).

## Awards and recognition

The CNRS has received numerous awards and recognition for its contributions to science and research. The organization has been awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics, the Crafoord Prize, and the L'Oréal-UNESCO Award for Women in Science.
